name: 4-amino-3-nitrophenol
Reason: The compound 4-amino-3-nitrophenol has several functional groups that will influence its melting point. The base unit of the compound is phenol, which has a melting point of around 41 degrees Celsius. The presence of an amino group (-NH2) typically increases the melting point due to the introduction of hydrogen bonding, which is a strong intermolecular force. We can estimate this increase at about +50 degrees Celsius. Additionally, the nitro group (-NO2) is an electron-withdrawing group, which can also increase melting point due to the stabilization of the compound and additional intermolecular forces like dipole-dipole interactions. We can estimate this contribution to be around +60 degrees Celsius. There is also a hydroxyl group (-OH) already included in the base phenol unit whose effect has been considered in the base melting point. The overall predicted melting point is the sum of the contributions from the base unit and the functional groups.
Test (Predicted reason):
- Basic unit, phenol, has a melting point of 41.5°C. 
- The amino group (-NH2) is capable of hydrogen bonding, which significantly increases the melting point. This effect can be estimated to be around +50°C. 
- The nitro group (-NO2) is an electron-withdrawing group that can engage in intermolecular interactions, such as dipole-dipole interactions. This can be estimated to raise the melting point by around +30°C. 
- The hydroxyl group (-OH) is capable of hydrogen bonding, which can further increase the melting point. This effect can be estimated to be around +20°C. 
The combined effects of these functional groups on the melting point are additive.
